Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Instrument Development: Additive Rapid Prototyping Instrument (ARPI)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
MRI: Development of an Additive Rapid Prototyping Instrument for Advanced Manufacturing Research

Additive manufacturing (AM)-- the process of making a three-dimensional object from a digital computer model-- has the potential to revolutionize the way things are made. It enables design-driven and personalized manufacturing and the production of complex parts and structures. This rapidly evolving technology is being used by companies in industries ranging from healthcare to national defense but with current AM processes there are limitations in the accuracy and quality of the parts that can be made. This Major Research Instrumentation award will support the development of an integrated Additive Rapid Prototyping Instrument with multiple AM operations and real-time advanced sensing and control functions. This will enable fundamental research on the fabrication of products from different materials with intricate features and enhanced mechanical properties. This award advances the frontiers of AM and fundamental multidisciplinary research and education and promotes technology transfer to enhance the competitiveness of the US manufacturing sector.


The significant feature of this instrument will be its ability to realize multi-physics, multi-material and multi-scale processes for improved accuracy, surface finish, and properties. This multi-functional modular system will perform laser-engineered net or powder bed fusion, with subsystems for accuracy and property enhancements, and process monitoring, operating in a common command-and-control environment. The instrument will integrate several processing energy sources with computer numerically-controlled precision and high-speed high-sensitivity instrumentation. The dominant scientific and technological challenges to be addressed are the realization of the integrated system and the understanding and modeling of hybrid processes and process chains in such an environment. Incorporation of sensors and instrumentation for in situ real-time measurements of relevant physical process parameters as a function of time and position will be crucial to the understanding of interactions that take place between processing energy sources and the workpiece. This fundamental knowledge provides a key stepping stone in advancing the frontiers of additive manufacturing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The purpose of the project was to build a unique state-of-the-art integrated Additive Rapid Prototyping Instrument (ARPI) for supporting fundamental research, technology development and education in the fields of multi-physics (hybrid) additive manufacturing (AM)/3D printing processes, machines and systems for the rapid realization of products requiring multi-material structures and multi-scale features. AM processes constitute rapidly evolving technologies for advanced product developments in sectors ranging from healthcare to national defense.

ARPI is a multi-functional modular open-architecture 3D manufacturing platform in which each module can operate either in a stand-alone or in an integrated manner in a common command-and-control environment. With real-time process monitoring and control and secondary operations performed in parallel or subsequent to either laser-engineered net shaping (LENS) or powder bed fusion (PBF) type AM processes, ARPI provides an integrated processing environment for enhancing part accuracy, surface finish, and material properties beyond the current capabilities of traditional LENS and PBS processes.

Intellectual Merit. ARPI integrates various processing energy sources with the technology of ultra-precision computer numerically controlled precision manufacturing and high-speed and high-sensitivity instrumentation. The hardware and software designs support the processing of arbitrary industrial-scale specimens with unprecedented precision and unique processing abilities not previously explored or available in existing systems. It is the first instrument of its kind, thus providing broad opportunities for multidisciplinary research and development of AM processes, methods and equipment. The salient feature of ARPI is its ability to realize multi-physics, multi-material and multi-scale processes. The dominant scientific and technological challenges addressed in ARPI are the physical realization of the integrated system, gaining an understanding and modeling of the hybrid processes and process chains it supports. The incorporation of instrumentation and sensors for the in situ real-time measurement of the relevant physical process parameters as a function of time and position provides crucial supporting prerequisites for fundamental investigations of the interactions that take place between the processing energy sources and the components being manufactured.  

Broader Impact. ARPI provides for: (1) new opportunities for multidisciplinary research, education, and training in materials science, mechanical and manufacturing engineering; (2) the development of novel processing methods in AM with the potential of resulting in a substantial leap over existing capabilities; (3) the necessary capabilities to build complex 3D components; (4) the study of the influence and of the consequences of processing methods on functional responses and properties of the manufactured components; (5) experiences and a model for the conception of new manufacturing equipment and systems for AM processes; and (6) the possibility that ARPI may be developed into a commercial tool, thus providing commercialization opportunities and wider access for the community, both for basic research and industrial applications.
